RMP Executive Summary
Pasadena, TX: Baker Petrolite-Bayport Facility (US)
1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Baker Petrolite LLC is committed to operating the Bayport Manufacturing Facility and all associated processes in a safe manner for the protection of the environment, the public population, and its employees.  Baker Petrolite LLC has established a system to help ensure the safe operation of the processes at the Bayport Facility as part of this commitment. One part of this system is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at the Bayport Facility and complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) regulation 40 CFR part 68, "Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (RMP rule).  The RMP rule requires the submission of a risk management plan (RMPlan) describing the risk management prepared for the Baker Petrolite Bayport Facility.  The purpose of this document is to satisfy the RMP plan requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at the Bayport Facility.

By preventing accidental releases of hazardous substances, Baker Petrolite is committed to protecting its employees, the public population, and the preservation of the environment.  Baker Petrolite implements reasonable controls to prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances.  In the event of a significant accidental release, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. If a release event occurred, Baker Petrolite would evaluate the release, evacuate workers as required, and contact the LaPorte police department dispatcher to inform them of the release and mitigate or eliminate the consequences.  Baker Petrolite has established a program with the LaPorte Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), LaPorte Fire Department, and the Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) to warn the community that if a release occurs, i

t could affect the community.
2.	Regulated Substances Handled
Baker Petrolite is a specialty chemical manufacturer of chemical products for use in oil field production, refinery processes, and as additives for various end uses.   With the production of many chemical products, Baker Petrolite uses eight (7) chemicals above the RMP threshold quantities. They include anhydrous ammonia, aqueous ammonia, ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, formaldehyde, ethylenediamine, and cyclohexylamine. The covered processes involving these chemicals are Program 3 processes for RMP rule compliance purposes. The following is a summary of the individual chemicals and the covered processes:

1. Anhydrous ammonia is stored in cylinders (1,754 lbs. each) and is used as a neutralization chemical agent to produce chemical intermediates.
2. Aqueous ammonia is stored in a pressure vessel-type storage tank within a dike containment. It is used as a neutralization chemical agent to produce chemical intermediates. 
3. Ethylene oxide is stored in two pressure vessel-type storage tanks, each with individual dike containment. Ethylene oxide is used in the ethoxylation of chemical intermediates. 
4. Propylene oxide is stored in two pressure vessel-type storage tanks, each with individual dike containment. It is used in the propyloxylation of chemical intermediates. 
5. Formaldehyde is stored in an aboveground vertical fixed roof storage tank. It is used in the production of chemical resin-type intermediates. 
6. Ethylenediamine is stored in an aboveground vertical fixed roof storage tank. Ethylenediamine is used in the production of chemical intermediates.
7. Cyclohexylamine is stored in drums and totes.  Cyclohexylamine is used in the production of blends. 

3.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program & Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Baker Petrolite has performed an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) to estimate the potential for an accidental release of a regulated substance to affect the pu

blic or the environment. The OCA evaluates worst-case scenarios (WCS) and alternative-case scenarios (ACS).  Baker Petrolite does not expect a WCS ever to occur. However, an ACS is a more realistic scenario that is more likely to occur.  The ACSs will help the LEPC to improve the community emergency response plan.  If interested, please contact our RMP coordinator Thomas Rios (832) 572-0418.
The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Bayport Facility. The processes at the Bayport Facility are not only regulated by the EPA RMP regulation but also by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) process safety management (PSM) standard. This summary addresses the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system to implement the accident prevention program.

Process Safety Information
Baker Petrolite keeps various technical documents used to help maintain the safe operation of processes.  Chemical-specific information is provided in safety data sheets (SDS). The SDSs are maintained and located online and can be accessed through the Baker Hughes Intranet. Block diagrams on PSM-covered processes are included in the Bayport PSM Manual and the maximum intended inventories of PSM-covered chemicals. Additionally, safely designed upper and lower limits of pressure, flow, composition, and temperature for PSM-covered processes are included in the Bayport PSM manual. The Bayport facility maintains the processes within these limits by using process controls and monitoring equipment, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems. The Bayport PSM Manual includes an evaluation of the consequences of deviation. The plant engineering department maintains the following information: materials of construction, piping and instrument diagrams, electrical classifications, relief valve design, ventilation system design, design codes, engineering standards employed in the plant, and safety system interlocks/suppression systems.

A program is in place for all process equipment to comply with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.
Baker Petrolite LLC uses the following safe work practices to ensure worker and process safety: control of entry/presence/exit of support personnel, lock-out/tag-out procedures, procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials from process piping or equipment, hot work permit system, and confined space entry program. These procedures form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Process Hazard Analysis
Baker Petrolite has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with various processes. Each process is systematically examined to identify process hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. Baker Petrolite performs these systematic reviews using the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis method. The HAZOP team consists of people with operating, maintenance, and engineering expertise. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the processes and accident prevention and suggests additional measures as needed. The team findings are documented, and all approved changes are implemented for corrective action. These periodic reviews are conducted on a 5-year cycle and will continue until the covered process is no longer operating. Again, the team findings are documented and retained.
Operating Procedures
Baker Petrolite LLC maintains written procedures for the manufacture of specialty chemicals. Each specialty chemical requires a specific "batch ticket" to manufacture that chemical, intermediate, or finished product. These "batch tickets" contain particular information on raw materials required, quantities of raw materials, reaction conditions, and any chemical-specific conditions for that chemical reaction. In addition to the "batch tickets," there are written plant standard operating procedures (SOP) which cover activities that are genera

l to many everyday tasks. These SOPs cover general tasks such as forklift operations, chemical storage tank filling, container storage, sampling procedures, housekeeping, and other activities familiar to many of the specialty chemical processes. Emergency shutdown instructions are in the Bayport Production Standard Operating Procedure Manual (P-26, P-27, and P-28). The "batch tickets" are reviewed after each batch to reflect current operating practices.

Training
Baker Petrolite LLC has a company training program for all plant operations employees. New employees receive basic orientation training in plant operations regardless of their previous experience level. After completing this training, the new operator is assigned to a more experienced operator with job experience to perform the duties and tasks in the new job assignment. After the new operator can demonstrate the ability and knowledge (through oral and written testing) to perform the job in a safe manner on his own, he will begin to work alone. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training.

Mechanical Integrity
The chemical processes at the Bayport Facility have hazards that must be controlled to maintain safe operation. The prevention program previously summarized applies to all the Program 3 EPA RMP-covered processes at the Bayport plant. These prevention program procedures help prevent potential accident scenarios caused by human or equipment failures. Baker Petrolite LLC has safety equipment and features on all units to help contain or control a release and reduce the consequences of a release. The safety features used on various chemical process equipment for release detection are hydrocarbon detectors with alarms, process alarms, and video monitors. The types of equipment features used for containment or control of releases are process relief valves, tank scrubbers to control vessel or storage tank emissions, valves to permit isolation of process equipment, automated shutdown sys

tems (high level, high temperature, no agitation) for specific process parameters, dike walls, backup electrical power generator for specific critical equipment, and backup firewater pumps. Baker Petrolite LLC uses the following equipment for release mitigation: Fire suppression and extinguishing systems, firewater deluge systems for specific processes, trained emergency response personnel, and personal protective equipment.
Management of Change
Baker Petrolite LLC has a management of change (MOC) plan (GPS2000) for handling changes to chemical processes in the plant. This system is described in the Bayport Safety and Environmental and SOP manual. The approved MOC files are maintained in the plant engineering department. The MOC changes are communicated to the process operators on the production "batch tickets." Baker Petrolite LLC provides training for the plant employees involved in processes where significant process hazards exist.
Pre-startup Reviews
Baker Petrolite LLC conducts Pre-Startup Safety Reviews for new facilities or facility modifications that require a change in process safety information. This review provides an additional check to ensure construction is by design specifications to maintain process safety.
Baker Petrolite LLC has practices and procedures to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process equipment at the Bayport facility. These procedures for inspections and maintenance are found in several of the Bayport SOP manuals, namely, the Maintenance SOP manual, the Safety and Environmental SOP manual, and the Bayport Production SOP manual. The Maintenance Department Supervisor maintains records for equipment inspections and testing. "Safety Priority" work orders are issued to correct problems or process defects.
Compliance Audits
To help ensure that an accident prevention program is functioning properly, Baker Petrolite LLC periodically conducts program audits. The Baker Petrolite Corporate Industrial Health, Environmental, and Safety (HS&

E) department conducts safety audits every three years. In response to the audit teams findings, corrective actions are taken.
Incident Investigation
Baker Petrolite LLC investigates all incidents that could have resulted in a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, significant property damage, personal injury, or environmental loss. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident. Corrective actions are taken in response to the team's findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for five years.
Employee Participation
The Bayport Facility encourages plant employees to participate in all process safety management and accident prevention areas.  Employee participation ranges from updating technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. The employees can access all information in the Baker Petrolite plant accident prevention program. One of the ways process safety and employee safety issues are addressed is in the monthly plant safety committee meetings. The committee consists of plant operators and management personnel.
Contractors
Baker Petrolite LLC uses a contractor specializing in contract maintenance and other outside contractors for construction activities as required. Because the contractors work on or near process equipment, there are procedures in place to ensure that contractors perform their work safely, have sufficient knowledge and skills, are aware of the hazards in their work area, understand emergency procedures, follow site-specific safety rules, and inform Baker Petrolite personnel of any hazards they find in the area. Baker Petrolite LLC has written procedures for the contract maintenance contractor and the other contractors performing construction projects. The contractor maintenance contractor employees must attend orientation sessions for plant-specific procedures, chemicals used in the plant, and

Baker Petrolite LLC policies. A separate procedure (HSE-046) for construction contractors covers plant procedures, safety rules, and emergency procedures pertaining to their work. In addition, Baker Petrolite LLC evaluates prospective contractor safety programs and performance when selecting a contractor.
4.	Five-year Accident History
Baker Petrolite Chemicals has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases of regulated substances. Due to our stringent release prevention policies, no accidental releases have occurred. 
5.	Emergency Response Plan
Baker Petrolite LLC maintains a written emergency response program to protect the plant employees, the public, and the environment. This program consists of procedures for responding to all releases, including flammable and toxic chemicals. The emergency response plan covers all aspects, including first aid, medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response organizations, and the public in the event of a significant release. There are procedures for maintenance, inspection, testing, and use of emergency response equipment. Plant employees receive annual training in these procedures to maintain their specific emergency response duties. The program is updated as needed to reflect changes in personnel and plant processes. The overall emergency response program is coordinated with the LaPorte LEPC. Baker Petrolite LLC has 24-hour communications capability with appropriate LEPC and CIMA emergency response organizations. This also provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, and facilitating quick response. In addition to regular meetings (LEPC and CIMA), Baker Petrolite LLC conducts periodic emergency drills that involve emergency response organizations.
6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Baker Petrolite LLC constantly strives to improve the safety of the plant processes through periodic safety reviews, i

ncident investigations, and soliciting safety suggestions from the plant employees. In the next 5 years, we plan to make the following changes:

1. Installation of new blast-resistant control rooms for both Plant 2 & 3 Units.
2. Replacement of the entire fire water line with new piping.
3. Upgradation of our DCS system to improve plant automation.
